Mean predator/prey mass ratio

Gustav

5/17/2021

Source: vignettes/ppmr.Rmd
ppmr.Rmd

Diet

The rate at which a predator of species i and size w consumes biomass coming from a prey of size w’ is \[e_i(w'|w) = (1 - f_i(w)) \gamma_i(w) \phi_i(w,w') \left(\sum_j\theta_{ij}N_j(w')+\theta_{iR}N_R(w')\right)w'.\] Romain says he has already coded up a function to calculate this, where of course the integral is replaced by the Riemann sum.

When we integrate over all prey sizes we get \[E_i(w) = \int d_i(w'|w)\,dw',\] which is what the mizer function getEReproAndGrowth() calculates.

Average predator/prey size ratio

We are now interested in the average of the predator/prey size ratio weighted by its contribution to the predator’s diet. \[ m_i(w) = \frac{1}{E_i(w)}\int \frac{w}{w'} e_i(w'|w)\,dw'.\]

However, as Ken suggested, it might be more sensible to look at the average of the log of the predator/prey size ratio

\[ l_i(w) = \frac{1}{E_i(w)} \int \log\left(\frac{w}{w'}\right) E_i(w'|w) \,dw'.\]

I think this might give a nicer graph. Again of course the integral will be replaced by a Riemann sum.
